item.title: THE KINDLING OF THE FIRE, THE PRAVARA, AND THE TWO LIBATIONS (ÂGHÂRA) OF BUTTER.
item.description: 01 With the fire-wood (idhma, lighting material) the Adhvaryu lights (indh) the fire: hence it is called fire-wood. And with the kindling verses (sāmidhenī) the Hotr̥ kindles (sam-indh, to make blaze): hence they are called kindling verses. 02 He (the Adhvaryu 1) says (to the Hotr̥): ‘Recite to the fire as it is being kindled!’ for it is to the fire, when it is being kindled, that he recites. 03 Here now some people say, ‘O Hotar, recite to the fire as it is being kindled!

item.title: UNKNOWN_TITLE
item.description: 01 He (the Āgnīdhra) now brushes the spoons 1 (with the grass-ends). The reason why he brushes the spoons is that the course 2 pursued among the gods is in accordance with that pursued among men. Now, when the serving up of food is at hand among men,– 02 They rinse the vessels, and having rinsed them, they serve up the food with them: in the same way is treated the sacrifice to the gods, that is to say, the cooked oblations and the prepared altar; and those vessels of theirs, the sacrificial spoons.

item.title: UNKNOWN_TITLE
item.description: 01 Now the sacrifice is the man. The sacrifice is the man for the reason that the man spreads (performs) it; and that in being spread it is made of exactly the same extent as the man 1: this is the reason why the sacrifice is the man. 02 The juhū (spoon) further belongs to that (man-shaped sacrifice), and so does the upabhr̥t; and the dhruvā 2 represents its trunk. Now it is from the trunk that all these limbs proceed, and for this reason the entire sacrifice proceeds from the dhruvā.

item.title: UNKNOWN_TITLE
item.description: 01 The Adhvaryu takes the sprinkling-water, and sprinkles in the first place the fire-wood 1, with the text (Vāj. S. II, 1), ‘A black deer, living in the den, art thou 2; I sprinkle thee, agreeable to Agni!’ He thereby makes it sacrificially pure for Agni. 02 He then sprinkles he altar, with the text (Vāj. S. II, 1), ‘Thou art the altar; I sprinkle thee, agreeable to the barhis (sacrificial-grass covering)!

item.title: UNKNOWN_TITLE
item.description: 01 They should be green (fresh); for that is (what constitutes) their living element, by that they are vigorous, by that possessed of strength: for this reason they should be green. 02 The middle stick he lays down first (on the west side of the fire), with the text (Vāj. S. II, 3), ‘May the Gandharva Viśvāvasu 1 lay thee around for the security of the All! Thou art a fence to the sacrificer, thou (art) Agni, invoked and worthy of invocation!
